channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: how to get money to where it’s needed fast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03605-2

Finance for coping with the harms of climate change must be disbursed swiftly and pragmatically. The world’s largest existing climate fund for supporting climate mitigation and adaptation provides lessons.
item.dc:title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: how to get money to where it’s needed fast
item.dc:creator: Laura Kuhl
Istiakh Ahmed
M. Feisal Rahman
Jamie Shinn
Johan Arango-Quiroga
Saleemul Huq

item.title: ‘Loss and damage’ — the most controversial words in climate finance today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03615-0

Crucial talks on how richer countries should compensate poorer countries for the effects of climate-related extreme weather are stuck. The COP28 climate summit must make a breakthrough.
item.dc:title: ‘Loss and damage’ — the most controversial words in climate finance today

item.title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: a mechanism to make it work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03578-2

Compensating for the devastating impacts of heatwaves, hurricanes and floods after they occur is too slow. With climate risks accelerating, the world must predict who needs funds and when.
item.dc:title: Climate loss-and-damage funding: a mechanism to make it work
item.dc:creator: Richard H. Clarke
Noah J. Wescombe
Saleemul Huq
Mizan Khan
Bert Kramer
Domenico Lombardi

item.title: People go the extra mile for food
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03617-y

GPS data reveal that people travel far from home to buy food in the United States, challenging ideas about how access to food relates to unhealthy eating habits.
item.dc:title: People go the extra mile for food

item.title: From the archive: a juice extractor in an insect’s gut, and amateur radio telephony
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03501-9

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: a juice extractor in an insect’s gut, and amateur radio telephony

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03572-8

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: AI should focus on equity in pandemic preparedness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03608-z

AI should focus on equity in pandemic preparedness
item.dc:title: AI should focus on equity in pandemic preparedness
item.dc:creator: Yuan Shen
Linghua Yu

item.title: Expose limitations of SDGs rather than trying to save them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03606-1

Expose limitations of SDGs rather than trying to save them
item.dc:title: Expose limitations of SDGs rather than trying to save them
item.dc:creator: Abhik Chakraborty

item.title: Deep-sea mining threatens jellyfish, suggests first-of-its-kind study
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03625-y

Sediment dislodged by ocean-floor mining could disrupt jellyfish metabolism, potentially causing the animals serious harm.
item.dc:title: Deep-sea mining threatens jellyfish, suggests first-of-its-kind study
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: China: personalized carbon accounting for consumers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03609-y

China: personalized carbon accounting for consumers
item.dc:title: China: personalized carbon accounting for consumers
item.dc:creator: Li Zhang
Lan Tao
Dongjie Sun
Fangyi Yang

item.title: The community should also support Palestinian scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03607-0

The community should also support Palestinian scientists
item.dc:title: The community should also support Palestinian scientists
item.dc:creator: Rana Dajani

item.title: Science in cities benefits rural communities, too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03571-9

Shouting about the far-flung impact of city-based research can help counter attempts at urban–rural division.
item.dc:title: Science in cities benefits rural communities, too
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: Iceland braces for volcanic eruption: what scientists are watching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03631-0

Researchers are tracking every aspect of the geological unrest, which began last month.
item.dc:title: Iceland braces for volcanic eruption: what scientists are watching
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: City-based scientists get creative to tackle rural-research needs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02992-w

Californian projects show how community engagement can break down urban–rural barriers in the United States.
item.dc:title: City-based scientists get creative to tackle rural-research needs
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Bright satellites are disrupting astronomy research worldwide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03610-5

A team of amateur and professional astronomers has determined that a satellite one-third of the size of a tennis court is one of the brightest objects in the sky — with dire consequences for ground-based astronomy.
item.dc:title: Bright satellites are disrupting astronomy research worldwide
item.dc:creator: Samantha Lawler

item.title: Is it too late to keep global warming below 1.5 °C? The challenge in 7 charts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03601-6

Chances are rapidly disappearing to limit Earth’s temperature rise to the globally agreed mark, but researchers say there are some positive signs of progress.
item.dc:title: Is it too late to keep global warming below 1.5 °C? The challenge in 7 charts
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Divide and conquer: exploiting entropy to grow nanoscale barrier materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03361-3

The full promise of materials structured at the nanoscale can be realized only if they can be manufactured more efficiently and at the sizes required for device integration. An innovative method takes advantage of thermodynamic and kinetic effects to control the growth of stacked 2D nanosheets that can be used for practical applications from the nanoscale to the macroscale.
item.dc:title: Divide and conquer: exploiting entropy to grow nanoscale barrier materials

item.title: How AI is expanding art history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03604-3

From identifying disputed artworks to reconstructing lost masterpieces, artificial intelligence is enriching how we interpret our cultural heritage.
item.dc:title: How AI is expanding art history
item.dc:creator: David G. Stork

item.title: Bridging the rural–urban health-care divide through community research partnerships
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02993-9

Scientists are working with Indigenous communities in Alaska to improve many facets of rural health.
item.dc:title: Bridging the rural–urban health-care divide through community research partnerships
item.dc:creator: Lucas Trout
Margaret Smith
Linda Joule
Stuart Harris

item.title: The highly mutated SARS-CoV-2 variant BA.2.86 is still neutralized by antibodies in the blood
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03376-w

The spike protein of BA.2.86 — a subvariant of Omicron — has a large number of mutations, and binds to its receptor in host cells with high affinity. Despite these characteristics, BA.2.86 is no more resistant to antibodies from vaccinated individuals than are the dominant variants that are currently in circulation.
item.dc:title: The highly mutated SARS-CoV-2 variant BA.2.86 is still neutralized by antibodies in the blood

item.title: Are rooftop solar panels the answer to meeting China’s challenging climate targets?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02991-x

Research is central to the success of major photovoltaic programmes in ramping up clean energy and alleviating rural poverty.
item.dc:title: Are rooftop solar panels the answer to meeting China’s challenging climate targets?
item.dc:creator: Yvaine Ye

item.title: Only 0.5% of neuroscience studies look at women’s health. Here’s how to change that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03614-1

A new initiative challenges the severe neglect of women’s brain health from puberty through to pregnancy and menopause.
item.dc:title: Only 0.5% of neuroscience studies look at women’s health. Here’s how to change that
item.dc:creator: Emily G. Jacobs

item.title: Wi-Fi for neurons: first map of wireless nerve signals unveiled in worms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03619-w

Studies find a densely connected network of neurons that communicate over long distances, rather than across synapses.
item.dc:title: Wi-Fi for neurons: first map of wireless nerve signals unveiled in worms
item.dc:creator: Claudia López Lloreda

item.title: Polio is on the brink of eradication. Here's how to keep it from coming back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03602-5

The campaign to eradicate polio could succeed in the next few years. But that’s just the beginning of a new challenge — keeping it away.
item.dc:title: Polio is on the brink of eradication. Here's how to keep it from coming back
item.dc:creator: Aisling Irwin

item.title: Swathes of Earth are turning into desert — but the degradation can be stopped
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03621-2

The latest United Nations data paint a grim picture. But countries that are getting land-restoration measures right provide some cause for hope.
item.dc:title: Swathes of Earth are turning into desert — but the degradation can be stopped

item.title: Microbiologist who was harassed during COVID pandemic sues university
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03518-0

At the heart of a New Zealand court case is the extent to which talking to the public constitutes an academic’s duty to society.
item.dc:title: Microbiologist who was harassed during COVID pandemic sues university
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: These bats are the first mammals found to have non-penetrative mating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03565-7

A European bat has been captured on film engaging in what appears to be an unusual reproductive strategy.
item.dc:title: These bats are the first mammals found to have non-penetrative mating
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: SpaceX Starship launch ends in explosion — what’s next for the mega-rocket?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03624-z

The craft travelled into space for the first time, before it self-destructed for unknown reasons.
item.dc:title: SpaceX Starship launch ends in explosion — what’s next for the mega-rocket?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Massive genetic study finds genes linked to cannabis addiction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03629-8

Data from more than one million genomes offer fresh insights into excessive cannabis use and its relationship to other diseases.
item.dc:title: Massive genetic study finds genes linked to cannabis addiction
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: These falcons excel at problem-solving — and outdo some of the world’s smartest birds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03563-9

A bird of prey called the striated caracara can figure out puzzles that are a struggle for Goffin’s cockatoos, which are known for their intelligence.
item.dc:title: These falcons excel at problem-solving — and outdo some of the world’s smartest birds

item.title: Eavesdropping on plant chatter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03613-2

Amie Fornah Sankoh studies how viruses commandeer plant communication at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center
item.dc:title: Eavesdropping on plant chatter
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: ‘Electrocaloric’ heat pump could transform air conditioning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03595-1

Heat pumps are ubiquitous in the form of air conditioners. Scientists just invented one that avoids harmful refrigerant gases.
item.dc:title: ‘Electrocaloric’ heat pump could transform air conditioning
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Daily briefing: Why these PhD scientists went into teaching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03633-y

Some academics seeking a stable and fulfilling career are swapping the laboratory for the classroom. Plus, CRISPR and e-ink investigate how cuttlefish camouflage and how bacteria might help purify rare-earth elements.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why these PhD scientists went into teaching
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why these PhD scientists swapped research for secondary-school teaching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03612-3

Students value being taught by real-life scientists with lived experience of life in the lab, say researchers who switched career.
item.dc:title: Why these PhD scientists swapped research for secondary-school teaching
item.dc:creator: Anne Marie Conlon

item.title: Migration isn’t increasing, border restrictions don’t reduce crossings — and other home truths
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03603-4

Prejudice, rather than facts, colours our views about human mobility, argues a new book. But the global shock of the COVID-19 pandemic means that the world is changing in front of our eyes.
item.dc:title: Migration isn’t increasing, border restrictions don’t reduce crossings — and other home truths
item.dc:creator: Alan Gamlen

item.title: ‘Extremely worrying’: Argentinian researchers reel after election of anti-science president
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03620-3

As part of his plan to address the country’s economic crisis, Javier Milei has promised to slash research funding and shut down key science agencies.
item.dc:title: ‘Extremely worrying’: Argentinian researchers reel after election of anti-science president
item.dc:creator: Martín De Ambrosio
Fermín Koop

item.title: How my MBA helps me keep my donor-funded research centre afloat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03592-4

Medicinal chemist Susan Winks shares how she keeps money flowing at the drug-discovery centre she helps to manage.
item.dc:title: How my MBA helps me keep my donor-funded research centre afloat
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: Microbial miners take on rare-earth metals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03611-4

As a tech-hungry world gobbles up rare-earth elements, researchers are adapting bacteria that can isolate and purify the metals in the absence of harsh chemicals.
item.dc:title: Microbial miners take on rare-earth metals
item.dc:creator: Amber Dance

item.title: Progress on plastic pollution treaty too slow, scientists say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03579-1

As national divisions widen over how to address the global waste crisis, researchers fight for more input into the process.
item.dc:title: Progress on plastic pollution treaty too slow, scientists say
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Record-breaking heat set to hit southern hemisphere as summer begins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03547-9

The northern hemisphere experienced a sweltering summer due to climate and meteorological patters. Scientists say the south will not escape.
item.dc:title: Record-breaking heat set to hit southern hemisphere as summer begins
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Botox’s paralysing effects can relieve an uncontrolled head tremor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03525-1

A bacterial toxin used to reduce wrinkles can also treat a common disorder in older people.
item.dc:title: Botox’s paralysing effects can relieve an uncontrolled head tremor

item.title: Why genes mean less than you think, and other reads: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03591-5

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Why genes mean less than you think, and other reads: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Dust: the tiny substance with enormous power
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03588-0

Jay Owens joins us to talk about her book Dust: The Modern World in a Trillion Particles.
item.dc:title: Dust: the tiny substance with enormous power
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson

item.title: CRISPR and ‘e-ink’: new tools could reveal the secrets of cuttlefish camouflage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03558-6

New technology moves scientists closer than ever to understanding how colour-blind cuttlefish pull off their kaleidoscopic patterns.
item.dc:title: CRISPR and ‘e-ink’: new tools could reveal the secrets of cuttlefish camouflage
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Hypotheses devised by AI could find ‘blind spots’ in research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03596-0

Artificial intelligence is asking questions that humans hope to answer.
item.dc:title: Hypotheses devised by AI could find ‘blind spots’ in research
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: EU allows use of controversial weedkiller glyphosate for 10 more years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03589-z

In the wake of a stalemate among member states, the European Commission has decided to approve the herbicide’s continued use.
item.dc:title: EU allows use of controversial weedkiller glyphosate for 10 more years
item.dc:creator: Barbara Casassus

item.title: Daily briefing: Origin of flashing space explosion remains mysterious
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03622-1

Flaring ‘Tasmanian devil’ space explosion baffles astronomers. Plus, how the high cost of the world’s first approved gene-editing treatment could limit its benefits and superconductor research enters a golden age.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Origin of flashing space explosion remains mysterious
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Scientific illustration: striking the balance between creativity and accuracy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03391-x

A misleading image in a medical textbook could have life and death implications, but some disciplines can deploy myth and metaphor to convey their science through art.
item.dc:title: Scientific illustration: striking the balance between creativity and accuracy
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.dc:title: Author Correction: Chromatin compartmentalization regulates the response to DNA damage

item.title: A Russian warship’s sinking is linked to strange weather pattern
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03527-z

Unusual temperature inversion might have helped Ukraine to sink the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet last year.
item.dc:title: A Russian warship’s sinking is linked to strange weather pattern

item.title: As an artist-scientist, ‘I’m obsessed with pigments’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03577-3

Biochemist Sierra Weir explores local ecosystems around Pittsburgh for art and inspiration.
item.dc:title: As an artist-scientist, ‘I’m obsessed with pigments’
item.dc:creator: Robin Donovan

item.title: Daily briefing: How ‘monkey laundering’ undermines research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03600-7

Laboratory monkeys that are illegally poached from the wild and falsely labelled as captive-bred can disrupt experiments and lead to unreliable data. Plus, how researchers have been affected by the Israel–Hamas conflict and the robot chemist that could help to make oxygen on Mars.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How ‘monkey laundering’ undermines research
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why superconductor research is in a ‘golden age’ — despite controversy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03551-z

Last week’s retraction dealt a blow to the search for room-temperature superconductivity, but physicists are optimistic about the field’s future.
item.dc:title: Why superconductor research is in a ‘golden age’ — despite controversy
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: How wild monkeys ‘laundered’ for science could undermine research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03533-1

Demand is fuelling an illegal trade. But smuggled monkeys carry diseases that can disrupt experiments and lead to unreliable data.
item.dc:title: How wild monkeys ‘laundered’ for science could undermine research
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: The Israel–Hamas conflict: voices from scientists on the front lines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03550-0

The deadly 7 October Hamas attacks on Israel, and Israel’s bombardment of Gaza, have upended lives — including those of researchers throughout the region.
item.dc:title: The Israel–Hamas conflict: voices from scientists on the front lines
item.dc:creator: Nature news team and freelance reporters

item.title: UK first to approve CRISPR treatment for diseases: what you need to know
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03590-6

The landmark decision could transform the treatment of sickle-cell disease and β-thalassaemia — but the technology is expensive.
item.dc:title: UK first to approve CRISPR treatment for diseases: what you need to know
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: The 3D printer that crafts complex robotic organs in a single run
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03568-4

Combining machine vision with contactless error correction allows for even more advanced multi-material printing.

item.title: How to 3D print fully-formed robots
item.content:encoded:

Printing multi-material objects in a single run, and the effectiveness of lifestyle interventions for preventing type 2 diabetes.

item.title: Leonardo’s construction design takes shape centuries later
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03528-y

Researchers make a 3D-printed beam based on the Renaissance polymath’s idea for a masonry structure.
item.dc:title: Leonardo’s construction design takes shape centuries later

item.title: Seabirds’ lonely travels pose a conservation challenge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03526-0

Tracking devices show that protecting these solitary wanderers will require regulation over enormous stretches of open ocean.
item.dc:title: Seabirds’ lonely travels pose a conservation challenge

item.title: Massive study assesses benefits of lifestyle changes on diabetes risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03580-8

A large diabetes prevention programme in the UK is put to the test, with promising results.
item.dc:title: Massive study assesses benefits of lifestyle changes on diabetes risk
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Single-cell, whole-embryo phenotyping of mammalian developmental disorders
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06548-w

A study reports single-cell RNA-sequencing profiles for more than 1.6 million cell nuclei from 101 whole mouse embryos including 22 mutant and 4 wild-type genotypes, from one experiment.
item.dc:title: Single-cell, whole-embryo phenotyping of mammalian developmental disorders

item.title: Bacterial cGAS senses a viral RNA to initiate immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06743-9

Staphylococcus CdnE03 cyclase recognizes structured RNA molecules produced by staphylococcal phages, triggering cyclic oligonucleotide production and, thereby, bacterial cell death—a mechanism of antiviral defence conserved across domains of life.
item.dc:title: Bacterial cGAS senses a viral RNA to initiate immunity
item.dc:creator: Dalton V. Banh
Cameron G. Roberts
Adrian Morales-Amador
Brandon A. Berryhill
Waqas Chaudhry
Bruce R. Levin
Sean F. Brady
Luciano A. Marraffini

item.title: Imaging inter-valley coherent order in magic-angle twisted trilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06663-8

Scanning tunnelling microscopy imaging of the correlated phases of magic-angle twisted trilayer graphene shows marked signatures of interaction-driven spatial symmetry breaking.
item.dc:title: Imaging inter-valley coherent order in magic-angle twisted trilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Hyunjin Kim
Youngjoon Choi

item.title: The social and structural architecture of the yeast protein interactome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06739-5

A protein interaction network constructed with data from high-throughput affinity enrichment coupled to mass spectrometry provides a highly saturated yeast interactome with 31,004 interactions, including low-abundance complexes, membrane protein complexes and non-taggable protein complexes.
item.dc:title: The social and structural architecture of the yeast protein interactome
item.dc:creator: André C. Michaelis
Andreas-David Brunner
Maximilian Zwiebel
Florian Meier
Maximilian T. Strauss
Isabell Bludau
Matthias Mann

item.title: Kinetic magnetism in triangular moiré materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06633-0

Minimization of kinetic energy leads to ferromagnetic correlations between itinerant electrons in MoSe2/WS2 moiré lattices even in the absence of exchange interactions.
item.dc:title: Kinetic magnetism in triangular moiré materials
item.dc:creator: L. Ciorciaro
T. Smoleński
I. Morera
N. Kiper
S. Hiestand
M. Kroner
Y. Zhang

A. İmamoğlu

item.title: Embryo-scale reverse genetics at single-cell resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06720-2

We present the ‘zebrafish single-cell atlas of perturbed embryos’, single-cell trancriptomic data of developing zebrafish embryos across various timepoints and with genetic perturbations.
item.dc:title: Embryo-scale reverse genetics at single-cell resolution
item.dc:creator: Lauren M. Saunders
Sanjay R. Srivatsan
Madeleine Duran
Michael W. Dorrity
Brent Ewing
Tor H. Linbo
Jay Shendure
David W. Raible
Cecilia B. Moens
David Kimelman
Cole Trapnell

item.title: Minutes-duration optical flares with supernova luminosities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06673-6

Observations of optical flares from AT2022tsd (the ‘Tasmanian Devil’) show that they have durations on the timescale of minutes, occur over a period of months, are highly energetic, are probably nonthermal and have supernova luminosities.
item.dc:title: Minutes-duration optical flares with supernova luminosities

item.title: CD201<sup>+</sup> fascia progenitors choreograph injury repair
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06725-x

Spatiotemporal regulation of wound healing in mice and humans occurs via retinoic acid and hypoxia signalling, which regulate the differentiation of CD201+ fibroblast progenitors into proinflammatory and myofibroblast states.
item.dc:title: CD201<sup>+</sup> fascia progenitors choreograph injury repair
item.dc:creator: Donovan Correa-Gallegos

item.title: Quantum gas mixtures and dual-species atom interferometry in space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06645-w

Using upgraded hardware of the multiuser Cold Atom Lab (CAL) aboard the International Space Station (ISS), Bose–Einstein condensates (BECs) of two atomic isotopes are simultaneously created and used to demonstrate interspecies interactions and dual species atom interferometry in space.
item.dc:title: Quantum gas mixtures and dual-species atom interferometry in space

item.title: Potentiating glymphatic drainage minimizes post-traumatic cerebral oedema
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06737-7

Acute oedema after traumatic brain injury is accompanied by the suppression of glymphatic and lymphatic fluid flow due to excessive systemic release of noradrenaline.
item.dc:title: Potentiating glymphatic drainage minimizes post-traumatic cerebral oedema
item.dc:creator: Rashad Hussain

item.title: Dynamic diagnosis of metamaterials through laser-induced vibrational signatures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06652-x

A high-throughput, non-contact framework is described that uses the laser-induced vibrational signatures of metamaterials to non-destructively quantify their omnidirectional elastic information, dynamic linear properties, damping properties and defects.
item.dc:title: Dynamic diagnosis of metamaterials through laser-induced vibrational signatures
item.dc:creator: Yun Kai

Washington DeLima
